H0.text: Gas → liquid → solid shows how frozen water changes as the temperature of the air increases.

H1.text: Solid -> gas -> liquid is the sequence that shows how frozen water changes as the temperature of the air increases.

H2.text: Liquid → gas → solid is the sequence that shows how frozen water changes as the temperature of the air increases.

H3.text: Solid -> liquid -> gas shows how frozen water changes as the temperature of the air increases.

A4.text: Familiar examples are the melting of ice or the boiling of water (the water does not instantly turn into vapor, but forms a turbulent mixture of liquid water and vapor bubbles).

A5.text: At a pressure of one atmosphere (atm), ice melts or water freezes (solidifies) at 0 °C (32 °F) and water boils or vapor condenses at 100 °C (212 °F).
